awd_titl_txt: RII Track-4: Pore-Scale Transport Phenomena in Li-O2 Battery Electrodes Characterized by Nano-Tomography
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical Description

Rechargeable batteries with high specific energy and power are the key for high-performance and long-range electric vehicles as well as many portable power applications. The lithium-oxygen (Li-O2) battery has great potential as the next generation energy storage technology. However, the current achievable specific energy (i.e., energy per unit mass) for Li-O2 batteries is a factor of ten lower than its theoretical limit and their current power performance are still far below the acceleration performance required for electric vehicles. Both of these limitations are partially due to the sluggish mass transfer of oxygen in the electrode. Increasing the specific energy requires fundamental knowledge of pore-scale material transport in battery electrodes. To fill this knowledge gap, the PI will work with collaborators at Carnegie Mellon University (CMU) to measure and reconstruct the pore-scale structure of Li-O2 battery electrodes and propose criteria for fundamentally improving the electrochemical performance of Li-O2 batteries. Research findings from this Fellowship will also be integrated into curriculum development efforts to transmit the new theory and knowledge to young researchers, train undergraduate and graduate students, and nurture a skilled and educated professional workforce to grow local industry and economy.

Technical Description

The collaboration with Prof. Shawn Litster and access to the unique X-ray Computed Tomography Facility (XCFT) at CMU, made possible by this Fellowship, is the key to reconstructing high-resolution (~50 nm) pore-scale structure and for subsequent studies of Li-O2 batteries. The reconstructed three-dimensional nano-tomography of customized battery electrodes will 1) be integrated with statistical models to transfer pore-scale morphology to electrode-level properties; 2) be coupled with fluid dynamics models to predict its electrochemical performance; and 3) facilitate the understanding of pore structure evolution caused by the solid Li2O2 precipitation/depletion during discharge/charge. The new knowledge and theory, as well as the new techniques, developed in this project will enable research and development of advanced electrode materials to significantly improve the specific energy and power of Li-O2 batteries. The profound scientific significance will last beyond this Fellowship and promote electrochemical technologies with high energy and power density such as fuel cells, Li-ion batteries, metal-air batteries, super capacitors, and redox flow batteries. The success of this project will initiate a longstanding collaboration between the PI and Prof. Litster to pursue new knowledge and foster more collaborative research between the University of Kansas and CMU. It also provides an excellent opportunity for one graduate student to receive systematic training on conducting scientific research, initiating collaborations, and disseminating research findings each summer.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.inst_name: University of Kansas Center for Research Inc
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF KANSAS CENTER FOR RESEARCH INC

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This research aims to understand the pore-scale transport phenomena of Li-O2 battery electrodes governed by the pore size, structure, connectivity, and wettability through a new collaboration with Prof. Shawn Litster at Carnegie Mellon University (CMU). This project has pursued new knowledge in pore-scale electrode geometry and pore-level transport phenomena that govern the electrochemical performance of battery and fuel cell electrodes. The new knowledge, theory, and techniques, developed in this project will enable research and development of advanced electrode materials and fill the knowledge gap to engineer electrodes for energy conversion and storage. This research has a profound scientific significance that will last beyond this Fellowship and promote electrochemical technologies with high energy and power density, such as fuel cells, Li-ion batteries, metal-air batteries, supercapacitors, and redox flow batteries.

The research team has been productive throughout the project with multiple journal publications (and submissions) generated from this project. The major accomplishments include:

  • Develop a parallel computing algorithm to generate 2D and 3D digital battery electrodes from 2D images and/or slices of microCT and nanoCT tomography. Results have been reported in a manuscript published in the International Journal of Energy Research.
  • Test mass-produced graphene, synthesized by Dr. Christopher Sorensen?s group at KSU using a unique detonation approach, as the Li-O2 battery cathode material. The customized graphene materials is at least one order of magnitude cheaper than commercial carbon nanoparticles. Graphene with tailored properties can produce higher discharge capacities and better stability than commercial carbon nanoparticles. Experiments results are reported in a manuscript submitted to the Journal of Electrochemical Energy Conversion and Storage. 
  • Applied vertically aligned carbon nano fibers (VACNFs) with a coating of Ni and PtRu alloy, grown by Dr. Jun Li?s group at KSU, as the Li-O2 battery cathode material. The VACNF electrodes produced higher discharge capacities and were more stable than commercial carbon nanoparticles. Experiments results will be reported in a manuscript to be submitted. 
  • Used ionic liquids (ILs) from Dr. Mark Shiflett?s group at KU as electrolytes of Li-O2 batteries. ILs have much lower evaporation rates and are more chemically and thermally stable than organic electrolytes. They are promising electrolyte materials for open systems like Li-O2 batteries. Li-O2 batteries with ILs have been tested at various temperatures (Room Temperature, 35oC, and 60oC). Experimental results have been reported in a manuscript submitted to Applied Energy. 

 

Research results have been published in the following journal paper:

[1]         Andre Adam, Fangzhou Wang, Xianglin Li, "Efficient Reconstruction and Validation of Heterogeneous Microstructures", International Journal of Energy Research, https://doi.org/10.1002/er.8578

[2]         Syed Shoaib Hassan Zaidi, Christopher M. Sorensen, Xianglin Li, "Incorporation of Novel Graphene Nanosheet Materials as Cathode Catalysts in Li-O2 Battery", Journal of Electrochemical Energy Conversion and Storage, Submitted.

[3]         Syed Shoaib Hassan Zaidi, Rajkumar Kore, Mark B. Shiflett, Xianglin Li, Effects of Operating Temperature on Lithium Oxygen Battery with Ionic Liquid-Based Binary Electrolyte, Applied Energy, Submitted.

[4]         Syed Shoaib Hassan Zaidi, Sabari Rajendran, Archana Sekar, Jun Li, Xianglin Li, "Vertical Aligned Carbon Nano Fibers as Stable Oxygen  Electrodes of Li-O2 Battery", In Preparation.

[5]         Fangzhou Wang, Paul K. Kahol, Ram Gupta, Xianglin Li, ?Experimental Studies of Carbon Electrodes with Various Surface Area for Li−O2 Batteries?, ASME Journal of Electrochemical Energy Conversion and Storage, 16 (2019) 041007.

[6]         Camila Zequine, Sanket Bhoyate, Fangzhou Wang, Xianglin Li, Khamis Siam, Pawan K. Kahol, Ram Gupta, ?Effect of solvent for tailoring the nanomorphology of multinary CuCo2S4 for overall water splitting and energy storage?, Journal of Alloys and Compounds, 784 (2019) 1-7.

[7]         Camila Zequine, Fangzhou Wang, Xianglin Li, Deepa Guragain, S.R. Mishra, Khamis Siam, Pawan K. Kahol, Ram Gupta, ?Nanosheets of CuCo2O4 As a High-Performance Electrocatalyst in Urea Oxidation?, Applied Sciences, 9 (2019), 793.

[8]         Camila Zequine, Sanket Bhoyate, Khamis Siam, Pawan K Kahol, Nikolaos Kostoglou, Christian Mitterer, Steven J Hinder, Mark A Baker, Georgios Constantinides, Claus Rebholz, Gautam Gupta, Xianglin Li, Ram K Gupta,  ?Needle grass array of nanostructured nickel cobalt sulfide electrode for clean energy generation?, Surface and Coatings Technology, 354 (2018) 306-312.

 

The project has also provided training and professional development for K-12, undergraduate, and graduate students and disseminate results to communities of interest.

  • The PI has hired and trained four undergraduate students (one of them is from the under-represented minority group), three course project teams (with 4-5 undergraduate students each), and three Ph.D. students during this project.
  • The PI has led and participated in four Summer Camps (the four camps in 2019 and 2020 have been canceled) with about 60 middle school and high school participants.
  • The PI has participated in a faculty debate focus on the future of transportation organized by KU ASME chapter in Dec 2021. More than 50 undergraduate and graduate students and some faculty members attended the debate. The two debaters also answered many questions from the audience. 

The PI highly appreciates the funding support from NSF.


Last Modified: 11/07/2022
Modified by: Xianglin Li
